ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class was a broad overview of jazz historiography that gave me a wide and useful bibliography for deeper reading in the future. I feel that we touched a lot of important work that I will revisit in the future, and that it gave me a general sense of the shifts and changes in writing jazz history over the twentieth century and into the present. I have a better sense of the major issues, writers, and debates in the field and feel better equipped to set my own work alongside the field.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The lack of a central syllabus made it hard to know what to expect from the course as a whole, it felt like continuity was lacking a bit.

Many of the readings in the first half of the class were very repetitive so that each week we read quite a bit but without necessarily gaining new insights or perspectives. We also only engaged with the music in one class which was a bummer. I really enjoyed the OHAM project and wish we had done more with that.

I believe the class was well organized over the weeks of readings - I felt clear and recognizable threads and debates that shifted over the course of several weeks. It gave me a clear introductory sense to what the field has looked like and what it looks like now, with great starting points to dive in deeper in several different areas.

I do feel that sometimes the readings felt overly heavy/broad. The choose-your-own-adventure reading assignments ("read whatever looks interesting to you from this book") were creatively stimulating and interesting, but led to some dead class discussions that felt frustrating at times. I'd love to see a little more coherence/structure, especially when a lot of the class had not read much jazz material before.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. This class was a broad overview of jazz historiography that gave me a wide and useful bibliography for deeper reading in the future. I feel that we touched a lot of important work that I will revisit in the future, and that it gave me a general sense of the shifts and changes in writing jazz history over the twentieth century and into the present. I have a better sense of the major issues, writers, and debates in the field and feel better equipped to set my own work alongside the field.

extras.title: MUSI 475 01/MUSI 675 01 - Writing the History of Jazz
